lines.text: You got a lot of morons in your family? 'Cause that could be genetic.
Keep me posted.
Any cases you don't want us to keep you posted on? What's the point in saying that?
OK, then, get outta my office.

[after Theo walks in on her getting out of the shower]
Did you drop Theo off at school?
I dropped him off at Hooters. He insisted.
I heard something in your voice, Andy, when you called me.
I guess what you heard didn't include the words coming out of my mouth.
I heard something and I checked my intuition, afterwards by prayer.
Katie, this has gotta stop. After God tells you what to do, if I'm involved in the message, you check back with me.
I was holding that deck for someone else.
Does the guy you were holding it for call you "my friend the moron"?
Don't you keep a daily log or something?
Daily log. What do I look like, Captain Kirk?

[while examining the body of a decapitated man whose head is sitting in his own lap]
You don't often encounter this method of suicide.
Marina. Strangled and raped. What is wrong with this country?
What's wrong with this country? I'll tell you what's wrong; it's all these foreigners coming over here.
Detective Sipowicz here is one of the few Native American Poles.
So, Greg; you know my dad, huh?
Yeah, from task forces and such; never worked in the same squad.
Listen, what do you know about 'Dutch Boy'?
When your dad was working a foot beat in Brooklyn, he walked by Miller's Hardware...
Yeah, I know the place.

Anyway, Clark noticed the door was open. It's a two story; street level and basement. Anyway, your dad goes in and when he goes into the basement; he sees what he thinks is a guy holding a gun. He identifies himself and when the guy doesn't drop the gun; Clark pulls his gun and shoots
[starts laughing]
. Clark's on the floor, calling for backup when he notices that the guy hasn't moved.
[laughing harder]

Anyway, he grabs his flashlight and notices that there's this white powder all over him. Then he notices that what he shot was a full size advertisement for 'Dutch Boy' paints and what he thought was a gun was the guy's paint brush. Meanwhile, he shot the brush off and there's two holes in the dummy's crotch. Man, he really got his balls broke over that one and...
[notices the stunned look on Clark's face]
uh...
Uh, of course, anyone could have made the same mistake.
Yeah, sure, could have happened to anybody.
get enough self-respect so when some fool starts talking to you like a nigger, you don't go half nuts and jam yourself up needing to prove he isn't right.
You got some funny ideas about self-respect.
My idea's when I hear an ass out in the field braying, I don't feel any deep need to start braying back.

[an overweight woman has demanded to see Sipowicz]
Andy, there's no easy way to say this, but Jeri is having issues with Diane and Jill. She's demanding to see you.
That ain't goin' to happen.
Diane and Jill think she's painted herself into a corner with manslaughter and it doesn't need to go that way. Anyway, she says either she talks to you or she lawyer's up.
That's what she needs to do then. Maybe we don't do enough of that.
[Looks at Simone]
See, this amuses you because you don't attract psychotics.
No, it doesn't. Well, yeah, it is amusing; but this could be real serious.
What happened, Vince?

Two guys came in the bar, ordered a drink, then pulled their guns and held up the place. Then all of a sudden they started shooting. I pulled my piece and shot back. I think I hit one, but then I went down.
But you weren't hit, were you?
No, chest pains. One of the guys left holding his shoulder. I wonder why I got chest pains at that moment?
Might be a sign from God to stay out of these titty bars, Vince.
All right, into the cage for a while.
For what?
For breaking balls. You give me no cooperation, I'm gonna run you for warrants in every jurisdiction in America.
Man, go out and get shot in the street.
Yeah, why don't you write that up for Reader's Digest? "My Worst Day Ever So Far" by Julio.
As it happens, the courts have upheld that a confession can be obtained by ruse or trick, so long as an innocent man wouldn't be deceived.
There's a relief.
But that doesn't make me any more comfortable with what you've done.
What's your name again?
Arnold Rosenthal.
Yeah, well, Arnold, why don't you leave me your card, and I'll be in touch the second that your comfort becomes important to me.
I don't know what Sylvia sees in you.
Dickhead.
I've got a big problem.
Oh, that's third floor. We're small to medium problems down here.

[after confessing to a robbery-homicide]
Money from the safe stashed in my apartment, black leather bag under some skin magazines in the corner behind the bed. I want to use that to pay for a lawyer.
Don't exactly work that way, Big Rick, but if they try at the trial passing you off as the mastermind, you tell 'em what you just said.

[Andy and Sylvia are having to adjust to the new baby]
Andy, do you remember having sex?
Aren't you afraid we'll wake up the baby?
Well, you'll just have to hold off on doing your Tarzan yell and beating your chest.
Yeah, I guess I could not do that this time.

[Sylvia has surprised Andy by getting in the shower with him]
Uh, Sylvia; you know I usually wash that part of my body down there myself.
Would you like me to stop?
Um, no. You seem to be doing a pretty good job of cleaning it.
[Fancy has been briefing Rodriguez]
Well, that's about it. You know, you haven't asked me any questions about the squad.
Yeah, guess I better do that; wouldn't want to appear apathetic. Any squadroom romances I need to be aware of?
None right now.
Okay. Any old school detectives that care more about solving cases than making the bosses happy?
Yeah. Sipowicz. He's... unique.
Is he a good detective?
If a member of my family was murdered, I'd want Sipowicz to catch the case.
I guess that's it then. Good luck, Captain.
The future keeps telling us what the past was about. You make the past mean different things by the way you use the time that comes after.
Romeo's a rage-a-holic, which means he's often pissed off, unlike the vast majority of us gliding along devil-may-care.
What's wrong with John babysitting?
He's gay, that's what's wrong with it.
I mean, c'mon, Andy, how long you known him?
A long time, and he's been gay every day of it.
I'm not a kid anymore, Simone. If you can't be kind about the people you feel kindness towards, you're no damn good.
if we're still drawing breath, we have a chance to do something on our shortcomings besides piss and moan.
How many times you want to get hit?
You know, the last time you hit me I jumped up and sat on my own testicle.

[Indicating discomfort about the hidden mike taped to his crotch]
This is uncomfortable.
The alternative location is up your ass.
Alllll right. Let me learn to live with this.
How you been feeling, Vince?
I told you. I have generalized coronary artery disease, abnormal in the thallium stress test, and now I'm having difficult urinating.
Coronary system failing, urinary system failing. Now he's at the stage, you ask him how he's feeling, he tells you.
How's the drying out going?
Helps when the first week's unconscious. Now I go two, three minutes where booze never crosses my mind.
That was positive, wasn't it? "Our pleasure"?
Fair.
What should I have said? "Our pleasure, rooty-toot-toot"?
[Cohen is trying to get back together with Kirkendall]
OK, here's your chance, but if you get belligerent with her again, everyone is this squad will take it very personal.
I understand.
If you don't understand now, you will about two seconds after you do it.
Suspects only get one phone call; so, you need to decide whether to call your lawyer or your drug dealer.
Unless they are the same person.

[making an announcement at the end of the shift]
Could I have everybody's attention! Connie and Me are taking Theo to Disney World. Anybody's got anything to say about it; speak up now.
So, uh, have a wonderful time.
He's the fast-talker of the partnership, while you take care of the silent, brooding chores?

[to Danny]
You remind me of Donnie Osmond with your partner's personality.
Agent Frances, I'm proud to say I've got all of Donnie's albums, including Mormon Hymns To Federal Agents Who Steal Their Weekly Paychecks.
You pay a toll for ongoing uncertainty.
You think you're a psychiatrist?
No, I'm a Polack detective, knows you get away with murder, you leave the crime scene and you go about your life. It's you, you intelligent types, you always got to provide an alternate suspect.
She make any derogatory references?
She said you were old and bald.
Old?
Bald?
We got the weapon from your apartment there, Rick.
Always a right move tossing the piece, Rick, though at the time it may seem wasteful.

[a suspect has demanded a phone book to call an attorney]
Oh, you want a phone book, huh?
[rips a phone book in half]
Okay, you look in that part and I'll look in this part.
Damn! Now, wait a minute. A brother like you don't know his own strength! Tell me again what you want to know!

[to Lt. Fancy]
Any breaks on the street shooting? I see you have your ace detectives Medavoy and Martinez on the case.

[to Kirkendall]
I don't suppose you have any worthwhile leads in your case?
Hey, kiss my ass, Cohen.
Not an entirely unappealing thought, detective. I'll be in Anti-Crime if you need me.
[Martinez is trying to make small talk with Lesniak after he finds out she's gay]
So, ah, Greg tells me you're gay now. How's that workin' out for you?
Fine. I'm in a stable relationship. James, I just didn't want you to keep hoping for something that wasn't going to happen.
[Medavoy and Jones are discussing a DOA]
Some of these working girls tell me this guy was a pimp. Imagine that; a white pimp. I mean, how does that happen, D?
Equal opportunity, Greg.
[Jones walks out of the shower to find Haywood in his apartment]
I thought about what you said. You're right, I am uptight and have a hard time being spontaneous. So...
So, what does that mean?

[removes her coat revealing sexy lingerie]
So, we have about an hour before we both have to get to work. Any ideas?
Theo walked in on me while I was getting out of the shower this morning.
Well, was this a glimpse or what?
Everything, I mean the Full Monty.
Well, at least he has something interesting to use during sharing time at school this morning.
[Clark finds that his father has moved all his belongings into the hall]
Dad, what's all my stuff doing out here?
Are you going to do what I told you and leave the 15th?
No!
You goin' to keep working with that bum Sipowicz?
Yeah.
Then you are leaving this house.

[after being shot]
Andy, take care of the baby!
[an older woman is coming on to Sorenson]
You know, sad thing is, back when I was drinking, many's the night I'd have thrown a hump into that.

My father died when I was like six years old. My mother, she couldn't take care of me and my sisters so she send us over here to live with her sister. I was born in Norway, but over here we lived in Albany. So, was I like your first Norwegian screw?
Not even close.
We're going to check out the other building this wacko manages.
[to Jones]
You might want to talk to this guy; he's carrying on about black demons and voices.
What, do you want me to go in there with my tribal outfit on?
[Disgusted, Sipowicz leaves]

[to Fancy]
Do you want me to go in there?
Well, do you have a tribal outfit?
What's open?
Not the coffee room.
Why 'not the coffee room'?
Lt. Fancy and Lt. Abner are in there with the door closed. They are having a frank discussion.
A very, frank, discussion.

[to Jones]
Don't go in there unless you hear glass breaking.
[Jones and Sipowicz are questioning a suspect]
Man, I can't go to no jail! What am I going to do about my bar?
Padlock it, Elmo, and reopen in three to five.
Three to five days?
Check out Elmo; Mr. Positive Thinking.
That's three to five *years*, nitwit.

[the squad is fed up with the controlling behavior of Lt. Bale]
I expect to be kept informed of everything that is going on in this squad at all times.
I'm planning to take a crap later. Would you like to be kept informed about that?
[Sipowicz is returning Bale's credit card that was found on a gay hustler]
Listen, when we were tossing this guy's apartment, I found this. Thought you might want it back. Got to figure, a guy like this is probably dealing in stolen credit cards from all over
[walks out as Bale looks stunned]

[about the credit card]
Detective; you know something about me and I want to know what you intend to do about it.
Lieutenant, all I know is I found your credit card and returned it to you. That's all I know and all I want to know. 'Night, boss.
Thank you, Detective.
Sipowicz, I heard from a friend of mine that oversees the sergeant's exam. You passed.
I did?
Just thought you might want to know ahead of time, before it becomes public. Congratulations. So, you ready to become a boss?

[Slightly stunned]
I guess I'll find out.

[looking at Simone]
"Protude the point for me..."

[Simone uses his middle finger to get the pen point out]
"I keep sticking myself in the eye."
You were pushing it, now you're under arrest. You're a collar, you understand that?
You guys are fags, right? You're fags from some women's group.
That don't make us bad people.
I don't take that from anyone, that what-do-you-expect thumb stuff.
Where's a good homicide when you need one?
Why are you so viciously callous?
It's how I deal with my continuous grief.
He needs to be tranquillized.
You pull a tranquillizer gun on me and the safari stops at the dentist! He's got the wrong elephant.

[Sipowicz suspects Russell is drunk on a bar stakeout]
What the Hell are you doing?
Acting like a slut. Isn't that what the boss wants?

[Medavoy has found out Lesniak is gay]
But, but you had a boyfriend!
And now I have a girlfriend, okay?

[Rodriguez has announced he is leaving]
If this is about Ortiz, deal with it. But if you're leaving because you're pissed off about the outcome of the trial, stay and fight ot! Leaving is a punk move and you know it!
Ortiz is none of your business; and I've never punked out on anything in my life.

[to his AA? sponsor, whose son keeps beating him up]
"Regret for the past is a waste of spirit." You told me that, remember?

Ok, Nicki; we know you and Derek planned to steal Beller's art. Now. Derek pulling a gun on Detective Sipowicz moves him to the top of the list. What you want to do is try to help yourself by wearing a wire when we put you two together and getting Derek to admit that he was the one who planned the whole thing.
If I do that, will I be implicated in the theft?
You're already implicated, Nicki; your cooperation in helping us nail Derek will buy you some good will with the DA and the judge.
This is where you want to say yes, Nicki.
[Jones is questioning a suspect]
Now, Arnell; I'm going to ask you some questions and I don't want you to lie to me. Where were you last night?
Man, I was home sleeping all...
[Jones slaps Arnell, knocking him out of the chair]
Arnell, I told you not to lie to me.
Pete Magrini is a rat bastard prick who deserves the needle for killing his wife who was my best girl friend!
And how do you know this, Angela?
He told he during an intimate moment.
So, Pete Magrini told you during an intimate moment you were having with him while you were Dino's girlfriend and his wife's 'best girl friend'.
Hey, I'm trying to give information here; not nominate myself as the next Mother Teresa. I'm tired of being a sexual football.
Did Pete tell you he killed his wife and put her in a 50 gallon drum hidden in a building he used to own?
No; he told me her body was buried behind his cousin Tommy's house in Englewood Cliffs.

[Jones has been questioning a rapper about the shooting of another rapper]
You know, I'm glad your lawyer showed up, 'cause now I can tell you what I really think. I think you are a punk-ass bitch wannabe thug just like Jenksy and Andre said. Don't like it? You wanna jump; jump.
[Rapper just looks at him]
That's what I thought.
[Danny has been manipulated by a Federal agent and furious about it]
Well, you'll have to work that out with the bosses, 'cause my inclination is to knock your teeth down your throat for moving me around like a gutter bum.
[Sipowicz is supervising his first crime scene as a uniform sergeant]
All right, all right, step aside, homicide detectives comin' through.
[shows his shield to Sipowicz]
How long you been waitin' to say that?

[laughing]
Every day since you were promoted.

[Murphy and Ortiz are watching Sipowicz reprimand a uniformed officer]
Hey! Get that damn car out of here! You're blocking the ambulance. What do you think you're doing?

[shaking her head and smiling]
Sergeant Sipowicz.

[Sipowicz shows up at a crime scene]
Hey, Andy, what are you doing here? I thought when Bale's shooting was solved, you were going back to uniform.

[looks at Sipowicz and smiles]
Go ahead, tell them.
They gave me the squad. Chief of D's told me last night at Medavoy's racket.
Really? Why didn't you tell anybody?
I didn't want to distract from Medavoy's night. Anyway, it went out this morning.
Well, I don't know that I can work for you.

[smiling]
I don't know if any of us can.

[going along with the joke]
That's OK. I was planning on bringing in my own people anyways.

[Medavoy has been testifying before IAB]
Whew, I'm glad that's over. Where's the lieutenant? I need to fill him in on what happened.
Lt. Fancy left with Detective Jones to pick up a suspect. Detective Jones felt that the suspect needed to be picked up immediately and no one else was here, so...

[Nervously]
Baldwin had to get the lieutenant to cover for me and help pick up a suspect? How was Fancy? Was he, he upset or anything?
Actually, he was smiling and seemed to be looking forward to it.

[Fancy has been catching hell all day from the chief]
Uh, excuse me, lieutenant. This guy we've got in the pokey gave us a place to pick up the suspect in that shooting this morning. Greg's at IAB and everyone else is out canvassing. Should I call Anti-Crime to go with me to pick up this guy?

[Looking at the phone and all the paperwork]
No, I'll go with you.
You'll go? Are you sure? Don't you have other things to do?

[Phone begins to ring as Fancy picks up his coat]
Are you kidding? I'm going with you. John, I'll be on the air.
I find out you been lyin' to us, I'll personally come back down here and beat your ass.

[to Sipowicz]
You goin' to let him talk to me like that?
Well, you know how some guys are. We've been tryin' to get him in an aggression management class.

[when Kelly tries to hire him]
I think everyone is entitled to the best lawyer they can find, Detective. I just don't think they're all entitled to me.

[Fraker is drunk and accusing Rodriguez of turning him in]
You're a lying spic rat, Tony!

[standing up]
OK, Captain, now your choices are leave, or get your ass kicked!
I want Sipowicz here, now!
Leave now, Captain!
[Fraker pulls his pistol and shoots Rodriguez]

[discussing Det. Russell's choice to leave the 15th with Andy]
. I was sick in love with Diane. I guess I had too high an expectation.
That's just what I wanted tonight - just keepin' company with you.

[to a witness who's smoking in the car while on a stakeout]
Put that out; it's affecting my sinuses.
Gotta do something while I'm sitting here.
Why you gotta do something? Why can't you just be?
Be what?
Just be what you are.
I am being what I am. I'm a smoker.
[Connie has suspicions about Sipowicz and Russell]
You won't tell me what's going on with Diane; well, something is going on and I'm being lied to!
